title: Re: Movie thread
content:
Yeah, first two Aliens rock the house!

I saw Anchorman last night, I thought it sucked. But that is just me. Not up to par with Zoolander and Dodgeball.

I also saw most of Der Untergang (translated: "Downfall"). It is a German film about the last days of Adolph Hitler. It is a really well made drama about these Nazis watching everything around them fall apart. I would recommend it, but you have to concentrate and it is very serious.*** --- I Am Keen is hell bent for leather. Are you? --- ***

title: Re: Movie thread
content:
My parents got 'Strange Bedfellows' for free for spending over $50 at a shopping centre. I didn't bother watching it though. It looks boring.

The last movies i've watched are Face/Off, Ned Kelly and Goodfellas. I never watch movies, but since I was with some friends, they didn't give me much of a choice.

I thought Face/Off was really boring. The movie was incredibly predictable, and was basically a series of action sequences. [Yawn]

I thought Ned Kelly was really boring, I couldn't really care for it.

Goodfellas was interesting as it was the first R rated movie I ever watched (which is under Australian standards, which is the highest possible rating for a film), and I actually quite enjoyed it although the last 20 minutes of it was REALLY slow.

However the last DVD I bought was The O.C. Season Two, yeah, it's a guilty pleasure of mine. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-cheeky.gif[/img] -- Censorship is F**ked! --

title: Re: woah
content:
Finally, FINALLY saw The Matrix. Man, that movie rocked! And it got me thinking, too.___________________
DaVince, Yet Another Amateur Game Creator! :P

title: Re: woah
content:
Haha, it was about a time then! [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-grin.gif[/img] When I first saw it I was 12 or 13 I think. I almost freaked out and thought about it for hours before I could concentrate even slightly to something other stuff. I felt very depressed and void because it actually made me think that my mind really was trapped in some merciless machine world (ironically that was true in a way since I used computer a lot).

And when I walked out from the cinema after seeing Matrix: Reloaded I had same kind of philosophical uneasiness in my mind. I felt again a bit unreal. This time it didn't last very long, though.

It's strange how they don't really care at all if a movie is mentally disturbing when they give it age-ratings. If it has some violence or "bad language" they easily make it suitable only for more mature audience but if the movie can make one doubt the very existence or makes one worry about something so much that one almost loses one's mind they don't really consider that being worse than some violence and words. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-rolleyes.gif[/img] Movies that provide ideas and thoughts one has never thought should be considered quite harmful if the thoughts are negative or depressing.3D Realms: "Do you think there'll ever be a sequel to your game(s)?"
Tom Hall: "If I owned Keen, there sure would be. I don't consider that GBA game canon by any means."

title: Hmm.
content:
For as long as I can remember I've always sent myself into such existential states anyway. Don't need a movie to do it for me. I actually found the Matrix trilogy rather uplifting. Cave assectatorem Ductoris Alacris
